technical_details.execution_flow: Initial access via phishing emails with malicious Excel macros

detection_queries: DnsEvents | where QueryType == 'TXT' and Name contains_any ('async', 'rat') | summarize count() by ClientIP
EmailEvents | where AttachmentFileType == 'xlsm' or AttachmentFileType == 'xls' | where SenderDomain !in (trusted_domains)
data.key_findings: AsyncRAT campaign specifically targeting financial institutions using DNS tunneling for C2 communication - uncommon technique that bypasses many traditional network security controls. Initial vector is Excel macro phishing, suggesting user interaction required.

data.technique_name: BYOVD - Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver
data.attack_vector: Attackers load signed but vulnerable kernel drivers (RTCore64.sys, DBUtil_2_3.sys) to gain kernel-level access and disable EDR products by terminating protected processes or removing kernel callbacks
data.prerequisites: Administrator privileges to load drivers; vulnerable signed driver file; knowledge of driver exploitation techniques
data.detection_gap: Most EDRs don't properly monitor driver loads at kernel level. Many security products focus on user-mode hooks which can be bypassed once attacker has kernel access
detection_ideas: Monitor Sysmon Event ID 6 (Driver Loaded) for known vulnerable driver hashes
Track driver certificate signers - vulnerable drivers often signed by MSI, ASRock, Gigabyte
Monitor for minifilter removal events (EDR bypass indicator)
Alert on kernel callback removal attempts
Baseline normal drivers on systems and alert on deviations
Monitor for user-mode processes loading drivers (unusual pattern)
affected_products: Most EDR products with user-mode hooks only
Endpoint security products without kernel-mode driver monitoring
Products that don't validate driver certificates against revocation lists
data.mitigation: Enable Windows Defender Application Control (WDAC) to block known vulnerable drivers; Use Microsoft's recommended driver block list; Deploy Hypervisor-Protected Code Integrity (HVCI); Monitor and alert on driver loads; Keep EDR products updated with kernel-mode protection
data.key_takeaway: URGENT: If your EDR doesn't monitor kernel driver loads, you have a significant blind spot. Enable Sysmon Event ID 6 logging immediately and hunt for RTCore64.sys and DBUtil_2_3.sys. This technique is actively used by ransomware groups to disable your defenses before payload deployment.

data.tool_purpose: Information stealer malware targeting browser credentials, cryptocurrency wallets, and sensitive data
capabilities: Targets Chrome, Firefox, Edge password vaults
Exfiltrates browser cookies and autofill data
detection_methods: Monitor for CPUID instruction execution from suspicious processes
Detect timing-based evasion (suspicious Sleep() calls, GetTickCount() checks)
Browser process hollowing or credential file access from non-browser processes
Unusual access to browser LocalState/Login Data files
Network connections to known Lumma C2 infrastructure
Memory scanning for credential vault access patterns
telemetry_sources: File integrity monitoring on browser data directories
data.key_takeaway: Monitor for ANY non-browser process accessing Chrome/Firefox/Edge credential files. Detection query: DeviceFileEvents | where FolderPath contains 'Login Data' or FolderPath contains 'logins.json' | where InitiatingProcessName !in ('chrome.exe', 'firefox.exe', 'msedge.exe'). Initial access via SEO poisoning means users searching for legitimate software may download this - educate users and monitor for unusual browser data access.

data.attack_vector: Unauthenticated remote code execution via specially crafted HTTP requests to SSL-VPN portal at /remote/login endpoint
detection_methods: Monitor FortiGate logs for error code FGT_ERR_SSL_VPN_AUTH_BYPASS
Alert on unusual HTTP requests to /remote/login endpoints
Monitor for suspicious process spawns from fgfmd daemon
Network IDS rules for exploitation attempts
Monitor for post-exploitation activity from FortiGate devices
data.mitigation: IMMEDIATE ACTION REQUIRED: Patch to versions 7.0.14+ or 7.2.7+. If patching not possible: (1) Disable SSL-VPN completely, (2) Restrict SSL-VPN access via firewall rules to trusted IPs only, (3) Deploy Fortinet IPS signature 50123. Over 150,000 devices currently exposed.
data.key_takeaway: CRITICAL PRIORITY: If you have FortiGate SSL-VPN exposed to internet, assume compromise until patched. APT groups are actively exploiting this. Hunt for: (1) Unauthorized admin account creation, (2) Unexpected configuration changes, (3) Unusual outbound connections from FortiGate, (4) New VPN sessions from unexpected geolocations. Patch immediately or disable SSL-VPN.

data.detection_name: Cobalt Strike Beacon Detection via Network Telemetry
data.what_it_detects: Cobalt Strike beacons by analyzing network traffic patterns, timing jitter, and default TLS certificates - even when C2 communications are encrypted
data_sources: Endpoint network telemetry (Sysmon Event ID 3, EDR network events)
data.detection_logic:
KQL Query for Microsoft Defender:
DeviceNetworkEvents
| where RemotePort in (80, 443, 8080)
| summarize 
    RequestCount = count(),
    AvgInterval = avg(datetime_diff('second', Timestamp, prev(Timestamp))),
    StdDevInterval = stdev(datetime_diff('second', Timestamp, prev(Timestamp)))
    by DeviceName, RemoteIP
| where RequestCount > 10
| where AvgInterval between (30 .. 90)
| where StdDevInterval between (10 .. 45)  // Jitter detection

Additional detection: Monitor for TLS certificates with serial number 146473198 (default Cobalt Strike certificate)
data.tuning_recommendations: Tune AvgInterval and StdDevInterval ranges based on your environment's normal beacon patterns. Exclude known-good applications with regular polling intervals (software updaters, monitoring agents). Correlate with process reputation and signing information. Focus on unsigned or suspicious processes making network connections with regular intervals.
data.coverage: Detects: Default and poorly-configured CS beacons, beacons with characteristic timing patterns, beacons using default certificates. Does NOT detect: Heavily customized malleable C2 profiles, beacons using legitimate-looking timing patterns, beacons tunneled through legitimate services (e.g., via domain fronting), SMB beacons (no network traffic).
data.key_takeaway: Implement this detection immediately - it catches a significant portion of real-world CS usage where operators don't heavily customize their profiles. Combine with YARA rules for in-memory beacon detection and hunt for serial 146473198 in your TLS traffic. This is especially valuable for catching hands-on-keyboard activity during intrusions.
